user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtBinFile2Mem:
```c
bool UtBinFile2Mem(void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE *fp;
    bool  Success;

    Success = false;
    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
    {
        if (fread(Memory, Length, 1, fp) == 1)
        {
            Success = true;
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    else
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("UtBinFile2Mem: Error Opening %s: %s", Filename, strerror(errno));
    }

    return Success;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtBinFile2Mem:
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the function contains ordinary, reachable control flow constructs (the fopen/fread/fclose sequence, the Success variable assignment and the conditional that sets Success = true). These do not themselves create unreachable code under standard C semantics. The only potential source of unreachable code is whether UtAssert_Failed (which expands to a call to UtAssertEx) is a non-returning assertion handler (e.g. aborts, longjmps, or is marked noreturn). If UtAssert_Failed/UtAssertEx does not return, then the subsequent code (notably the final "return Success;") becomes unreachable. UtAssert_GetContext (provided) simply returns a context and does not affect reachability. Therefore investigation should focus on the implementation/attributes of UtAssertEx (and any platform-specific attributes that could make the macro call non-returning); no other fragments in the shown code indicate unreachable code.
